item.title: China’s Top Soy Sauce Maker Rises in Hong Kong Trading Debut
item.description: Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co., China’s biggest soy sauce maker, rose on its Hong Kong trading debut after its HK$10.1 billion ($1.3 billion) stock offering drew strong demand from investors.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Kelly Li

media:content.media:description: Foshan Haitian soy sauce. Source: CFOTO/Future Publishing/Getty Images

item.title: Stocks Slide on Mideast Tension, Fed’s Warning: Markets Wrap
item.description: Equities fell as the US weighs the potential for direct conflict with Iran, and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell warned of meaningful inflation ahead.
item.dc:creator: Joanne Wong, Jiyeun Lee

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker displays figures for the Nikkei 225 Stock Average, top, and the Hang Seng Index on a footbridge in Pudong's Lujiazui Financial District in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. The US has hit China with the biggest-ever tariff hike on almost all Chinese products, bringing total levies to at least 54%, a move that could decimate Chinese shipments to the world’s largest economy.

item.title: Oil Slips as Investors Watch for Trump’s Plan on Iran Conflict
item.description: Oil dipped after a volatile trading week as the market focused on whether President Donald Trump will plunge the US into the conflict between Israel and Iran.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

item.title: Gold Steadies After Fed’s Inflation Warning Triggers Decline
item.description: Gold steadied following a decline in the previous session triggered by Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell’s warning of inflation risks for the US economy.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Thai Stock Index Poised for Five-Year Low on Political Upheaval
item.description: Thailand’s equity benchmark index fell Thursday, heading toward its lowest closing level since March 2020 after the government’s second-largest party quit the ruling coalition, piling further pressure on Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra.
item.dc:creator: Eduard Gismatullin

item.title: Auto Tariffs Seen Hiking Car Prices by Nearly $2,000 Per Vehicle
item.description: Car buyers will bear the brunt of the $30 billion cost of President Donald Trump’s tariffs, driving up already high US auto prices by almost $2,000 per vehicle, according to consultant AlixPartners.
item.dc:creator: Keith Naughton

media:content.media:description: GM's Buick vehicles unloaded on a trailer truck at the Port of Incheon in South Korea. Nearly half of the vehicles GM sold in the US last year were built abroad. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Italy’s Bank Deals Trip Over Pushback From Investors and Rome
item.description: For almost a year now, Italy has been at the center of a renaissance in European bank takeovers, with at least half a dozen deals proposed. So far, most are stuck in political opposition and competing investor interests.
item.dc:creator: Sonia Sirletti, Julia Janicki

item.title: China Copper Smelters Match Record as Foreign Rivals Falter
item.description: Chinese copper production stayed at record levels last month, despite a plunge in the fees charged by smelters, piling the pressure on operations elsewhere in the world that compete for feedstock.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Winnie Zhu

item.title: China’s Biggest Soy Sauce Maker Rises in Hong Kong Trading Debut
item.description: Foshan Haitian Flavouring & Food Co., China's biggest soy sauce maker, rose 3.3% on its Hong Kong trading debut on Thursday. That's after its HK$10.1 billion ($1.3 billion) stock offering drew strong demand from investors. Bloomberg's Manuel Baigorri reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Vietnamese Dong Drops to Record Low as Asian Currencies Weaken
item.description: The Vietnamese dong fell, dropping below a record low it touched in April, as Asian currencies declined following a report the US is preparing for a possible strike on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Karl Lester M Yap, Linh Vu Nguyen

item.title: Platinum Rallies to the Highest Since 2014 Amid Market Tightness
item.description: Platinum extended a powerful rally to hit the highest level in more than a decade, with gains underpinned by a spike in demand and expectations for a market deficit.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie

item.title: Japan Firms Exit Tokyo Exchange at Record Pace in Delisting Rush
item.description: Japanese companies are leaving the Tokyo Stock Exchange at the fastest pace in over a decade, reflecting a surge in deals and management buyouts as they face more pressure to make better use of their capital.
item.dc:creator: Kentaro Tsutsumi

item.title: Philippine Central Bank Chief Calls Peso Intervention Futile
item.description: The Philippines will tolerate the slide in its currency to a 10-week low, with the central bank governor saying intervention won’t be effective in the face of global risk aversion.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo, Prima Wirayani

item.title: Uncertainty Drives Rotation Out of the US: Nomura's Nicholson
item.description: Geopolitical instability and ambiguity around tariff impacts are key factors shaping global markets, according to Gareth Nicholson, Nomura CIO and Head of Discretionary Portfolio Management. Ongoing uncertainty is also prompting a rotation of assets out from the US. He speaks on Bloomberg’s The China Show. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: LG Electronics Is Said to Consider Resuming IPO of Indian Unit
item.description: LG Electronics Inc. is considering reviving an initial public offering of its Indian unit as soon as September, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Julia Fioretti, Baiju Kalesh, Rajesh Mascarenhas, Yoolim Lee

media:content.media:description: Visitors walk past the logo of LG Electronics during the 2024 World IT Show in Seoul on April 18, 2024. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP) (Photo by JUNG YEON-JE/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: Jung Yeon-je/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Indian IT Stocks Become Investors’ Top Pick As US Growth Concerns Ease
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Shell Says Ships Cautious Around Iran Due to Signal Jamming
item.description: Shell Plc, one of the biggest traders of oil and natural gas, is “being very careful” with shipping in the Middle East due to the conflict between Israel and Iran, said the company’s chief executive officer.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Shery Ahn

item.title: GPS Jamming in Strait of Hormuz is Challenging, Shell CEO Says
item.description: Shell CEO Wael Sawan says ongoing signal jamming in the Strait of Hormuz is challenging and the energy company is being very careful with shipping in the region. Sawan also says the oil market is balanced at the moment. He speaks with Bloomberg's Shery Ahn at a conference in Tokyo. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The World’s Most Profitable Nickel Plants Face Cost Challenge
item.description: A pioneering group of Indonesian nickel smelters with the world’s lowest production costs has been hit by a jump in the price of a key raw material, crimping their profitability just as the market is saddled with a glut.
item.dc:creator: Alfred Cang, Annie Lee

media:content.media:description: The nickel processing complex operated by Harita Nickel on Obi Island in Indonesia.

item.title: Indonesia Plans to Punish Nickel Park for Alleged Breaches
item.description: Indonesia plans to punish companies for alleged environmental breaches at a huge industrial park that accounts for a large slice of its nickel output, casting a cloud over some of the nation’s largest suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Eddie Spence, Annie Lee

item.title: Kolmar Holdings Surges Second Day on Korea Beauty Empire Feud
item.description: Shares in Kolmar Holdings Co. surged as much as 26% on Thursday, extending the South Korean beauty conglomerate’s gains to a second day, driven by a feud within the founding family.
item.dc:creator: Shinhye Kang

item.title: Blackstone’s ASK Plans to Hire 70 Wealth Bankers in India
item.description: Blackstone Inc.’s ASK Group plans to hire 70 private bankers as competition heats up within India’s booming wealth management space.
item.dc:creator: Advait Palepu, Apoorva Ajith

item.title: QXO Offers to Buy Building Materials Company GMS for $5 Billion
item.description: QXO Inc. said it sent a letter to GMS Inc. proposing to buy the building products distributor for about $5 billion.
item.dc:creator: Michael Hytha

item.title: Korea’s Cuckoo Set for Malaysia Debut After Scaling Down IPO
item.description: A subsidiary of South Korean home-appliance maker Cuckoo Holdings Co. is set to go public in Malaysia after a scaled-down offering that’s expected to raise 395 million ringgit ($93 million).
item.dc:creator: Ram Anand

media:content.media:description: Cuckoo's outlet in Kuala Lumpur. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Malaysia FX Reserves at Three-Year High to Aid Ringgit Stability
item.description: Malaysia’s increasing currency reserves are bolstering its defenses against market volatility.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Morgan Stanley to Shutter Electronic Equity Market-Making Unit
item.description: Morgan Stanley is shuttering a unit focused on electronic market-making for US equity options, retreating from a corner of the derivatives landscape that’s grown increasingly popular with retail investors, even as trading volumes boom.
item.dc:creator: Justina Lee, Bernard Goyder

item.title: Hong Kong Dollar’s Volatility Fuels Talk on How FX Peg May Shift
item.description: A fresh debate about the sustainability of Hong Kong’s decades-long currency peg has analysts ruminating on what might eventually replace it.
item.dc:creator: Iris Ouyang

item.title: Fidelity, BlackRock Target Chinese Demand for Offshore Funds
item.description: Fidelity International is poised to offer products that attract mainland investors chasing higher returns from overseas funds, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Echo Wong

item.title: Encino Plans to Cut 121 Houston Jobs Amid $5.6 Billion EOG Deal
item.description: Encino Energy LLC, the Utica oil & gas driller that agreed to a $5.6 billion sale to EOG Resources Inc. last month, is planning to cut 121 workers at its Houston-area office, according to the Texas Workforce Commission.
item.dc:creator: David Wethe
